Progressive Evangelicalism is Dangerous for LGBTQ+ People

Emily Swan
Apr 1

Last week I wrote an article about the Wild Goose Festival inviting Shane Claiborne to speak. Having been outed and fired from an evangelical church and denomination in 2014, rarely do I poke the evangelical hornets nest. I now co-pastor a beautiful church, Blue Ocean Faith Ann Arbor, with Ken Wilson, and frankly my life is wonderfully free of the anxiety swirling in most of the wider church world about gender and sexuality. The position Ken and I find ourselves in is one of pastoring the wider church’s outcasts — especially LGBTQ+ people and their allies.

I don’t enjoy engaging in critique of progressive evangelicals because staying completely away from that stream makes my life better. Yet I also realize that, after being abused by that system and spending five years in trauma therapy healing and learning tools to better help me and my congregants, I’m in a unique position as a queer pastor to be able to see, name, and guide other LGBTQ+ people navigating relationships with people (and churches, theologies, and so on) in that vein. In that spirit, I want to better spell out why LGBTQ+ people deserve clarity in regards to how Christian leaders feel about same-sex church marriages and queer clergy.

Queer people have been abused by evangelicalism, including by “progressive evangelicals.” This is the word straight Christians are often reluctant to use: abuse. Naming it means we associate people we personally like with abuse, and we are reluctant to do that because progressive evangelicals are “nice people,” doing “good work.” No one wants to say: Shane Claiborne abuses LGBTQ+ people, participates in a wider system of abuse, and benefits from that system.

He’s a nice guy! He’s coming along. Isn’t there space for dialogue? Space to change?

At this point in time, it’s willful ignorance to neglect the abuse stories of LGBTQ+ people. (For a list of resources cataloging abuse, see the bottom of this article.) Yes, there is always space for dialogue and change, but NOT WITH AND AMONG THE PEOPLE YOU ABUSE.

An analogy: If a woman is beat up by her partner, she does not owe her partner yet another conversation to hear their justifications for the abuse, “grace and space for change,” or a microphone/platform for them to tell mutual friends how wonderful they, the abuser, are in so many other respects. The woman should leave. The abuser should receive grace and space for change, but that CAN NOT happen in the presence of the abused.

The abused woman does not owe any of those things — conversation, grace and space, or a platform — to the people in her family/friend system who watched the violent abuse cycle and never intervened. Those people, also, deserve grace and space to change, but not by working it through with the battered person. The abused woman needs a place to heal — a place where she is safe and can learn to trust her emotions without being manipulated by her abusers into thinking she should be “nicer” to them; that she should go back to them; that she should listen to their endless arguements; that she should repeat a cycle that has proven harmful. She does not need to listen to them claim they’re now the victims of her boundaries.

Additionally, a woman beat up by her partner does not owe her abuser (or the silent bystanders) “eventual reconciliation.” However, she can make the decision to reconcile if — AND ONLY IF — the abuser owns the specifics of their abuse, renounces any intention to continue the abuse, and is willing to make restitution.

When I’m addressing a group largely composed of people who have experienced brutality (a lot of my congregation), I focus on validating their pain; on the solidarity Jesus offers with those who suffer; on their essential human worth, dignity, and strength.

I also tell them that it is a healthy response to push away from people and systems who abuse them.

That, while they can and are asked by Jesus to forgive people, they do not have to reconcile. This is difficult, especially for people who grew up Christian and live under false expectations of excessive niceness. Who have not been taught the deep, difficult spiritual work of reconciliation — work that requires both parties to enact.

Reconciliation is an ideal goal for Christians, but as father-daughter duo Desmond and Mpho Tutu teach us in The Book of Forgiving, reconciliation can only happen when when the abuser owns the damage they’ve caused, apologizes, renounces continuing the harm, and offers any restitution demanded by the victim. Short of that, victims can not reconcile with their abuser.

I was abused by progressive evangelicals — by individuals within it, as well as by the system. So were many of my congregants. So were many people who attend the Wild Goose Festival. Progressive evangelicals are dangerous for queer people. If you’re straight, you may not be able to hear that. If you’re a progressive evangelical, it will probably make you feel angry and defensive, because you don’t want to think of yourself as dangerous, especially if you consider yourself affirming. But if you listen to the voices of those who have been harmed, you must accept this as true: progressive evangelicals are dangerous to queer people. Especially progressive evangelicals who think they’re not dangerous.

As someone who was abused by that group, I now draw healthy boundaries to protect myself and pastor congregants to do the same. It took me five years of therapy to unlearn the poor boundaries I learned in evangelicalism — boundaries that resulted in me reluctantly splaying my personal life all over the altar at the demand of a hostile crowd and allowing people to poke and prod at my most intimate relationship.

Many of my congregants have been through conversation therapy, have had family members refuse to see them, have been told they will go to hell, have been kicked out of homes, have been kicked out of churches, have been shamed in their faith communities by making public “confessions” of being gay, have attempted suicide, have been denied jobs, have experienced deep depression and chronic anxiety because of being rejected by people of faith, have been told the way they are attracted to romantic partners is intrinsically distorted. I’ve heard enough tearful stories — and lived my own — that I’ve evolved from “let’s all agree to disagree on this” to a position of protecting, defending, and advocating for the abused. At this point in time, choosing a “traditional” reading of Scripture over the cries of the oppressed is choosing to make an idol of the Bible over the one commandment that provides the lens for all Christian ethics: love your neighbor as yourself.

Through my own journey back to health, I’ve learned that I do not have to speak with my abuser(s) or with the people who stood there and watched the abuse happen. In Girardian terms — if you’ve studied the scapegoat theory of atonement — I don’t have to interact with the mob who stoned me. (Ken and I go through scapegoat theory in detail in part two of Solus Jesus: A Theology of Resistance.) In fact, it’s not healthy for me to interact with them. It’s also not healthy for me to interact with the people who watched the mob stone me but who did nothing.

While Shane Claiborne apologizes for the cruelty experienced by LGBTQ+ people within Christianity, he does not own his part in the abuse and I do not need to “dialogue” with him. In fact, Shane preached at the church that publicly outted and fired me for being gay less than a year after that fiasco. When I wrote the organization hosting the event, they said Shane didn’t have any issue with preaching there. He went to that church and used his power and influence to validate the mob that shamed and exiled 250 LGBTQ+ people and their allies. Shane stood with the men (all the leaders who did so were male — the women quit their jobs in protest and came to plant a new church with Ken and me) who threw stones at me and my friends and then claimed to share a gospel of justice with the crowd. Shane is not my friend, nor is he an ally of any LGBTQ+ person.

You might even say Shane and I proclaim a different gospel — he stands with the mob falsely accusing queer people of misrepresenting the image of God in the world through their sexuality. And, lest you now think queer people are part of a “mob” accusing conservatives, I falsely accuse him of nothing. Rather, I’m holding him and others like him accountable for the abuse resulting from their views. Abuse with a smile is still abuse. Just because you don’t pick up a stone to throw it yourself, and you tell the mob they shouldn’t be quite so mean, doesn’t mean you’re not part of the problem.

Shane is dangerous to queers. LGBTQ+ people deserve to know if someone is potentially harmful to them before they choose whether or not to attend that person’s session at Wild Goose. “Clarity is reasonable,” as our friends at www.churchclarity.org say.

How can Shane reconcile with the LGBTQ+ community?

He can publicly own that his personal views and his willingness to enforce exclusionary policies are part of the problem. No amount of “I’m sorry we’ve come across as hateful” can cover his own responsibility in that system. He can own that he sees his relationship with his spouse as inherently “holier” than mine and other queer partnerships, and that posture will always inhibit relationship with LGBTQ+ people. He can own that he publicly took a vow of celibacy in his 20s that he was unable to keep, and yet tolerates celibacy as a viable option for discipling queer people. He can own that he wonders if a child deserves a mother and a father, even while studies continue to show that children raised by same-sex couples are just as healthy and well-adjusted as children raised by straight couples — and sometimes even outperform them. (Shane wrote me such in an email a couple of years ago. If his view here has changed, I’m open to hearing it and will publicly correct it.)

Shane can offer to change his ways and demand that queer people be fully included throughout the community he leads. He can acknowledge and renounce the money he makes and the influence he enjoys from spaces that categorically reject LGBTQ+ people who are okay with their sexual orientation. He can use his influence to convert from operating in the spirit of the accuser to the operate in the spirit of the Advocate in regards to LGBTQ+ people.

Who has modeled reconciliation with the queer community well?

Rachel Held Evans, for one. She left evangelicalism and, when I asked her about her books being published by a conservative Christian publishing house who would never touch a book like Solus Jesus, she said she’d had to finish out an old contract but had moved her writing going forward.

For another, Jen Hatmaker. I didn’t know much about her work until I saw her speak at Wild Goose last year, but she publicly owned the harm she’d caused queer people and, through tears, asked for forgiveness. Powerful stuff. Not many people who are part of a scapegoating mob own their part and apologize.

Liz Dyer, the founder and leader of Serendipidydodah, an online organization made up of over 5,000 moms of LGBTQ+ kids who come from traditionalist faith communities. Liz is the chief Mama Bear, fighting for the lives of queer youth by helping their parents love and accept them unconditionally. And Sara Cunningham, who is a Mama Bear herself and also runs Free Mom Hugs.

Kathy Baldock, who researches and writes about the history of how anti-LGBTQ+ theologies crept into Bible translations and denominational policies, writes: “I have not found one compelling, well researched, historically contextualized, biblically sound, relationally accurate, medically fact-based book from the excluders. Not one.”

It’s cost them all, professionally and personally. And, not being queer themselves, these women act as true allies in having the endless conversations and dialogue with people like Shane and other “progressive evangelicals” so that we LGBTQ+ people don’t have to subject ourselves to continued abuse.

That’s heroic work. That’s work that I think could and should be highlighted at the Goose.

Abuse

Why do I relate to evangelicals — progressive and otherwise — as abusers?

My friend James Finn wrote an article last week where he cites multiple sources of data regarding the psychological abuse of imposing a “traditional” sexual norm on queer people. He also writes,

The Trevor Project cites a study by San Francisco State University that finds LGB youth rejected by families and caregivers due to their identities were nearly six times more likely to report high levels of depression and more than eight times more likely to have attempted suicide compared to LGB youth from accepting and affirming families.

The American Academy of Pediatrics finds 50% of female to male transgender teens attempt suicide, among other disturbing finds.

40% of homeless youth are LGBTQ+ — queer kids kicked out of conservative “Christian” households. Locally, our church supports Ozone House, an organization that houses homeless youth in Washtenaw County. Our friends there also tell us 40% of homeless teens are queer kids who have been ostracized by their “Christian” families — this lines up with national statistics.

My wife, Rachel Murr, is a community mental health therapist. For her Master’s thesis she wrote a book cataloging the experiences of queer Christian women who grew up in non-affirming traditions but who have managed to hold on to some form of spirituality. That book, Unnatural: Spiritual Resiliency in Queer Christian Women, was the very first testimonial book to come out of the evangelical orbit written by a woman and sharing female stories.

Lutheran (ELCA) pastor Emmy Kegler keeps a resource list here that includes many, many testimonies in book, video, and audio form of queer people who experienced abuse in evangelical systems.

My friend Jane Clementi founded and runs an anti-bullying organization, the Tyler Clementi Foundation, that she formed after her gay son committed suicide. That organization hosts resources for faith communities here.

Exodus International shut down in 2013 after seeing countless lives ruined and sexual orientations unchanged.

Wild Goose, you know all these things — you don’t need me to list the damage, which could go on and on … and on. You know abuse has happened. You know being outed, as I was, is abuse. You know being fired for being gay is abuse. You know conversion therapy is abuse. You know the traditional church stance is psychologically torturous and leads to higher levels of depression and suicide. You know celibacy isn’t a viable or healthy option for the vast majority of human beings.

You know these things. Help keep queers safe. All we ask is clarity so we can make healthy decisions for ourselves.
